title: Memory Helps, but Confabulation Misleads: Understanding Streaming Events in Videos with MLLMs
author: Gengyuan Zhang (Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München), Mingcong Ding (Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München), Tong Liu (Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München), Yao Zhang (Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München), Volker Tresp (Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München), ...
relevance_why: The memory modification techniques and the handling of confabulation could enhance memory-augmented systems in audio and speech research, such as improving audio generation and restoration methods.
background: The paper explores how integrating a memory mechanism can improve understanding of streaming video events, while addressing the issue of misinformation generated by models.
contribution: This paper introduces a confabulation-aware memory modification method to enhance event understanding in streaming videos, addressing the issue of misleading memories.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Existing methods primarily focus on holistic video understanding without addressing the challenges associated with streaming contexts and memory misinformation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work differentiates itself by implementing a targeted approach to mitigate confusion caused by generated memories, thus enhancing performance in real-time streaming scenarios.

key_innovation: Develops a mechanism to quantify and adjust the reliability of memories based on historical predictions, improving reference accuracy in sequentially unfolding events.
real_world_impact: This approach could significantly improve real-time multimedia processing applications, such as surveillance, automated video summarization, and more efficient multimedia content retrieval.
limitations: The paper acknowledges limitations in computational constraints and explores only limited model architectures for memory integration.

new_terms.confabulation: **Confabulation** refers to the generation of false or distorted memories by a cognitive process, often observed in the output of language models when they rely on past predictions.
new_terms.event-triggered memory: **Event-triggered memory** is a mechanism whereby the memory system updates based on sequential events in video, aiming to capture temporal relationships accurately.
